lots of
maintainers so for those of you who saw

will be a little bit repetitive but I'll
I'll try and make it interesting
linkerty has been around for almost 10
years we're going to have our 10-year
birthday celebration next year and we're
going to have a massive party in Cancun
everyone here is invited uh all expenses
paid just talk to the link maintainers
at the buoyant booth get your badge
scanned uh to be registered for this
free party um I put a picture here of uh
a cockroach from ancient Egypt
so sometimes this is kind of what it
feels like working on
linkerd for for 10 years people have
telling us this is have been telling us
this project isn't going to work and
we're going to be crushed by ISTO and
crushed by Google and crushed by
everything else and yet here we are
every morning still you wake up and
there's a cockroach staring at you a
little bit bigger a little bit
stronger it's not a very exciting not a
very appealing analogy but uh you know
sometimes you just have to be the
cockroach uh you know but why why have
been why have we been successful well
for for one reason I think which is
simplicity and and I talked about this
knitted castle versus Lego castle idea
and that you know both both types of
castles perform the same job but one of
them is easy to modify one of them is
easy to maintain and the other one is
not right the other one everything is
tangled together when you're designing
software it's very easy to end up with
the knitted castle it's very difficult
requires a lot of discipline and
forethought to end up with the Lego
castle of course that's the one that you
want as a user that's the one that you
want
um one thing that I'm particularly proud
of besides the fact that you know this
the cockroach is still here 10 10 years
later um is that we became a sustainable
project last year i think we're probably
the only service mesh project that can
truly say this um the company that
employs all the linky maintainers
buoyant became profitable became
profitable by selling distributions of
linkerty i think that's really really
good for the linker project in in the
CNCF ecosystem we we maintain this
polite fiction that we're all here for
kind of in harmonious community you know
for the greater good of mankind but the
reality is everyone here is paid to be
here everyone here is either here to to
to learn about technology or to try and
convince someone else to adopt or to buy
technology we were paid by our employers
to be here and all the technology that
we're talking about today is used for
commercial purposes in the vast majority
of cases so I think we can we can kind
of like if we want to be really honest
and upright about ourselves we kind of
have to ask okay if I'm adopting an open
source project how do I know that
project's going to be here for another
year how do I know it's going to be here
in another 10 years i think it's a
really important question especially as
the macroeconomic climate changes
especially as the world around us
changes you know um and so I'm I'm I'm
very proud about the fact that we can
say for linkard there is an economic
engine behind it that powers this
project um and we've been able to add
new maintainers and to increase project
velocity in a way that's really true to
the
ethos of the project
um I'll give you one little anecdote
which is we for a for a while we sold
support for linkery so you know it's
just an open source project and then you
know we'd sell support and what we found
is that a lot of people would have
support for a year and then they'd
cancel it because they were like well it
just works we didn't have to call you
why would we keep paying this well so
that was great from the product
perspective we're like great we we made
you know we found a way to uh have this
beautiful project that doesn't you know
require our our users to you know have
to ask us all these questions all the
time um obviously from the commercial
perspective that was terrible um so uh
we had to come up with a better uh a
better model and I I think I'm I'm
really happy with where he landed there
i think this is really unique in the
CNTF ecosystem um we've been here for 10
years i'm going to wrap up now you know
I think the goal for us should be to be
here for a hundred years i think we've
got another 90 years at least
directionally that we should be focused
on i think that's the one if you really
want to build software that people can
rely on you know and that's linkard's
kind of core job almost is providing
reliability then you have to have you
have to be able to make some strong
claims about how you're going to be here
um you know and and how you can truly
rely on linkd so a lot of what I spend
my time thinking about you know for
Linkerty is less the features and and
and things like that it's more like well
how do we you know if you put your faith
in us right you you bring Linkerty into
your ecosystem you put yourself on the
line for it you you fight for it at your
company you know how can we live up to
that promise how can we make you feel
confident that we will be here you know
in another two years another five years
another 10 years another 90 years um and
so I just want to say thank you because
it's because of you that we're able to
do this and my commitment to you as kind
of the the person who's funding linkerty
at least you know figuring out ways to
get the maintainers paid um is that we
are going to do our best to be there for
you and we're going to listen to you and
we're going to uh make sure that when
you have issues with linkertd or when uh
you have challenges that link can't
solve for you that we're going to listen
and we're going to do our best to to fix
uh those those problems for you um so
thank you everyone really appreciate not
just your usage of linkerty but also you
coming today and spending you know a
whole couple hours with us at linkerty
day uh it's great to to see people come
out and and say hi and please do
continue to talk to us at the the booths
and the project pavilions um there's a
lot more conversations ahead of us so uh
thank you very much for attending the
second ever linker day
